newsitem.title: CHILE: Chile sees $950 mln trade gap next year - Marshall.
newsitem.headline: Chile sees $950 mln trade gap next year - Marshall.

text.p: Chile can expect a $950 million trade deficit next year, much higher than this year's deficit and due mainly to lower copper prices, interim Central Bank President Jorge Marshall said.

In a speech to Congress giving the bank's preliminary 1997 economic projections, Marshall said the gross volume of Chilean exports will rise markedly next year -- up 11 percent for all exports and 14 percent for copper.
By value, total exports should rise about 5.5 percent.
But average copper prices next year will slump to about 95 cents a pound, accounting for much of the trade gap, he said.
The forecasts gave an overall picture of a "reasonable balance in external accounts," said Marshall.
The trade deficit will end this year at about $400 million, while copper prices are expected to end with a 1995 average of around 105 cents, according to most private forecasts.
Next year's slump in copper exports by value "will be partially compensated by the significant, 14 percent increase of sales by volume," said Marshall.
But no major price increases were expected on Chile's other main exports either, he said. After copper, Chile's top exports are paper pulp, fresh fruit and fishmeal.
Overall, Marshall's message was one of weaker growth, fiscal prudence and adverse conditions for export prices.

The government's current accounts deficit will widen to about $2.85 billion next year, or about four percent of GDP, he said. He attributed that deficit to this year's trade gap -- which he projected to be about $350 million -- and for higher service payments of about $300 million.
The balance of payments will post an overall surplus of $800 million next year, with a surplus in capital accounts more than making up for the current accounts deficit, said Marshall.
All told, Chile can expect a net capital inflow next year of $3.65 billion, about $3.1 billion of which are medium and long-term investments, he said.
New foreign investment should total next year about $1.7 billion, while new credit disbursements should total about $3.2 billion and amortizations about $1.8 billion, said Marshall.
